choices.text: Upstroke of the smooth muscle action potential
Plateau phase of the ventricular muscle action potential
Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential

questions.text: A/E the following are associated with increase in calcium conductance -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential

Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential is due to opening of voltage gated potassium channels and an increase in potassium conductance.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with severe migraine headaches that are accompanied by hemiparesis. Genetic analysis confirms the suspicion of an inherited channelopathy. The membrane potential will depolarize by the greatest amount if the membrane permeability increases for which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Sodium

Increasing the membrane permeability for sodium will cause an inward movement of sodium. Gain of positive charge causes the membrane to depolarize. Increasing permeability for potassium or chloride will cause the membrane to hyperpolarize.

choices.text: Impaired ATP production during muscle contraction
Impaired relaxation after sustained muscle contraction
Uncoordinated contraction of myofibrils within affected muscle fibres
Decremental force generation on repeated muscle stimulation

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of ongoing muscle weakness. He has noticed difficulty in climbing stairs at home over the last several months, and he has recently stopped playing cricket due to difficulty in bowling, specifically in lifting his arm above his head. The patient takes no medications, and he has no family history of similar muscle weakness. On neurologic examination, he is unable to lift his arms or legs against resistance. He undergoes a muscle biopsy to evaluate the cause of his proximal muscle weakness. Electron microscopy of the specimen reveals sparse transverse tubules in some of the muscle fibres. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this patient’s biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Uncoordinated contraction of myofibrils within affected muscle fibres T- tubules are formed by invaginations of the sarcolemma in skeletal and cardiac muscle. Located in the T-tubules are the DHPR (dihydropyridine) receptors which are voltage sensors in skeletal muscle. Ttubules allow the depolarization to spread rapidly into the interior of the muscle fibre. Conformational change of the DHPR and a mechanical coupling with ryanodine receptor on the L-tubule results in release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The release of calcium occurs uniformly throughout the fibre, allowing for synchronized contraction of myofibrils in each muscle fibre (muscle cell).

choices.text: Duration of its refractory period
Conduction velocity of its action potential
Overshoot of the action potential

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of an axon is most dependent on myelination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Conduction velocity of its action potential

Velocity of conduction of a nerve impulse depends on its diameter and presence of myelin.

questions.text: A 79-year-old man is in the second post operative day after a lap cholecystectomy. He suddenly stands after being supine since the day of the operation. As a result, which of the following hemodynamic variables will increase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Ejection fraction

On standing up from a lying position causes a decrease in venous return, cardiac output, stroke volume and blood pressure. Baroreceptor reflex increases sympathetic outflow which increases the total peripheral resistance, cardiac contractility, stroke volume, heart rate and ejection fraction. These changes in the cardiovascular system return the blood pressure toward normal.

choices.text: Increased left ventricular stroke volume
Delayed closing of the aortic valve
Delayed closing of the pulmonary valve

questions.text: 1. A 25-year-old man presents to his physician for an annual physical examination. He instructs the subject to take a deep inspiration. During this manoeuvre, the physician detects a splitting of the second heart sound. Which of the following is the mechanism underlying this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Delayed closing of the pulmonary valve

The second heart sound is associated with the closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves, resulting in a splitting of the second heart sound into two components. During inspiration the preload on the right heart is increased, resulting in a larger stroke volume. This causes a delay in the closing of the pulmonic valve and a prolongation of the interval between the two components of the second heart sound.

questions.text: Which of the following organs has the highest arterio-venous oxygen differences under normal conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Heart

Heart has a very high oxygen demand at rest. Because of the high rate of metabolism in the heart compared with its blood flow, it has the highest arterio-venous oxygen difference under normal conditions. The heart can extract a large amount of oxygen because of its high capillary density.

questions.text: A patient has an oxygen consumption of 240mL/min. His systemic arterial oxygen concentration is 180mL/L of blood and his pulmonary artery concentration is 160mL/L of blood. What is his cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

12L/min Cardiac output by the Fick’s principle C.O. = oxygen consumption per minute/ (arterio-venous oxygen difference in mL/L) = 240mL/min/ (180 – 160)mL/min = 240/20 L/min = 12L/min

choices.text: Left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with mitral prolapse is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of her cardiac function. Which of the following is the best indicator of the cardiac preload?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Left ventricular end diastolic volume

Preload is the load acting on the muscle before it begins to contract. Preload is the degree to which the myocardial fibres are stretched before they begin to contract. The variable which is most directly related to the initial length is the EDV. Although blood volume, CVP, PCWP can all influence preload, they exert their influence through changes in EDV.

questions.text: A balloon catheter is advanced from the SVC towards the heart. When the tip is in the RA, it is inflated to increase the atrial pressure by 5 mm Hg. An increase in which of the following is expected to occur in response to the elevated atrial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

ANP Increase in atrial pressure stimulates the atrial stretch receptors which in turn increase the secretion of ANP and decrease secretion of ADH, resulting in a natriuresis and a diuresis

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with history of difficulty in running, jumping and keeping up with other children in races. Examination reveals a footdrop, weakness, sensory loss and reduced reflexes. He also has a decreased conduction velocity and an X-linked mutation of connexin 32, consistent with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. The neuropathy and gait disorder result because connexin is an important component of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Gap junction Gap junctions are formed of proteins called connexons. Each connexon has 6 subunits called connexins which surround a central pore. Connexons of neighbouring cells are aligned with each other to form a gap junction. A gap junction forms a low resistance path for a bi-directional transport of ions and molecules with molecular weights up to 1000 Daltons from one cell to the other. Gap junctions thus allow a rapid spread of impulses from one cell to the other. CMT disease consists of a heterogenous group of inherited peripheral neuropathies. Demyelinating forms of CMT are classified as CMT1 and axonal form as CMT2. Transmission is most frequently autosomal dominant but may also be autosomal recessive or X-linked, like the mutation affecting connexin 32 (Cx32), located in the folds of the Schwann cell cytoplasm around the nodes of Ranvier. This localization suggests a role for gap junctions composed of Cx32 in ion and nutrient transfer around and across the myelin sheath of peripheral nerves.

questions.text: Blood is transfused into a patient whose baroreceptors are not functioning. The bp in these individual increases from 100 to 150 mm Hg. The same volume of blood is later transfused into another individual whose baroreceptors are functional. The increase in bp in the second individual is from 100 to 125 mm Hg. What is approximate feedback ‘gain’ of the arterial baroreceptors in the second individual when they are functioning normally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

-1 Gain = correction/ error The correction in bp by the baroreceptors is from 150 to 125 mm hg or a correction of -25 mm Hg. The corrected bp is 25 mm Hg more than the normal MAP of 100 mm Hg. That is, the error is +25 mm Hg. Gain = -25/+25 = -1.

choices.text: Net fluid reabsorption into pulmonary capillaries

questions.text: A patient with MI develops progressive dyspnea and hypoxemia suggestive of cardiogenic shock. She is transferred to the ICU and a Swan-Ganz catheter is inserted. The patient is found to have a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 25 mm Hg, which is indicative of a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Net fluid reabsorption into pulmonary capillaries

Normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 8-12 mm Hg. PCWP is also an index of pressures in the left atrium and in the LV at the end of diastole; that is, PCWP is an index of left ventricular preload.

PCWP of 25 mm Hg is indicative of left heart failure. Elevated PCWP will increase pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure driving fluid out of the pulmonary capillaries and decreasing net reabsorption of fluid into the capillaries.

choices.text: Blood pressure and heart rate increase
Blood pressure and heart rate decrease
Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases
Blood pressure decreases and heart rate increases

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy while playing cricket in the park is hit by the fast moving ball and sustains a skull fracture which compresses the underlying brain tissue. Which of the following will occur in response to an increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases

Increase in intracranial pressure decreases cerebral blood flow producing CNS ischemia. This in turn increase sympathetic discharge increasing the blood pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors producing a reflex bradycardia.

choices.text: Activity of the Na+- K+ ATPase will decrease

questions.text: An 72 year-old woman is brought to the with complaints of nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, and generalized weakness. Laboratory analysis reveals significant hyperkalaemia. Elevations of extracellular potassium ion concentration will have which of the following effects on the nerve membranes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

RMP becomes less negative

In hyperkalemia, the potassium gradient between the inside and outside the cell decreases. This reduces the rate of potassium efflux resulting in more positive ions inside the cell. This causes the RMP to become less negative or the cell depolarizes.

choices.text: V/Q ratio of the alveolus equals zero
Po2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air
Po2 of the alveolus will be equal to the mixed venous Po2
Increase in shunting in the lung

questions.text: Which of the following will occur if blood flow to an alveolus is totally obstructed by a pulmonary thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Po2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air

Pulmonary thromboembolism will result in areas of the lung that are ventilated but not perfused, yielding a V/Q ratio equal to infinity and an increase in alveolar and total dead space. The composition of air in the affected alveoli will be equal to the humidified inspired air.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male with emphysema presents for his annual pulmonary function testing to assess the progression of the disease. As a result of alveolar septal de-partitioning in emphysema, there is a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Diffusing capacity

Breakdown of alveolar walls (alveolar septal departitioning) and loss of pulmonary capillaries in emphysema decreases the surface area available for diffusion causing a decrease in diffusing capacity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female suffers from third degree burns over 75% of his body. Her effective circulating volume and renal perfusion pressure drop precipitously and the concentration of NaCl in the tubular fluid in the kidney decreases. These conditions will cause an increase in which of the following by the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Renin

Decrease in the effective circulating blood volume will cause an increase in renin secretion by the JG cells in the kidney. Increase in GFR, increase in the luminal flow rate and increase in sodium and chloride load in the tubular fluid will cause an increase in adenosine secretion from the macula densa cells. Adenosine causes afferent arteriolar constriction, decreasing the renal blood flow and therefore, the GFR.

choices.text: Intrapleural pressure in the affected area equals the atmospheric pressure
Chest wall on the affected side recoils inward
Hyperinflation of the affected lung
Mediastinum shifts to the affected side with each inspiration

questions.text: A 35 year-old healthy male suddenly develops shortness of breath and fatigue. A chest X-ray reveals pneumothorax of the right lung possibly due to rupture of a bleb on the surface of the lung. Which of the following changes occur on lung function because of pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Intrapleural pressure in the affected area equals the atmospheric pressure

Normally the intrapleural pressure is negative w.r.t atmosphere. When air enters the pleural space dye to an interruption of the pleural surface through either the rupture of the lung or hole in the chest wall, the pressure in the pleural space becomes equal to the atmospheric pressure. The lung on the affected side will collapse because of the lung’s tendency to recoil towards the inside and the chest wall on the affected side springs outwards. Because the intrapleural pressure is atmospheric the mediastinum shifts farther to the normal side with each inspiration.

questions.text: A 80-year-old woman resents with polyuria and polydipsia. Blood analysis reveals hypernatremia and urinanalysis shows hypotonicity with increased free water clearance. In which of the following conditions is an increased free water clearance a hallmark of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Diabetes insipidus

In Diabetes insipidus, lack of ADH causes excretion of large volumes of extremely dilute urine, increasing the free water clearance.

choices.text: All breathing movements will cease
He loses voluntary control over his respiration
Central chemoreceptors will no longer be able to exert any control over the ventilation
Involuntary control over respiration will be lost but voluntary control will be present

questions.text: An 38-year-old male is brought to the Emergency after being thrown from his motorcycle following a collision with a stationary trolley. It is determined that he has a brain transection above the pons. How will this lesion affect the control of breathing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

He loses voluntary control over his respiration

Transection of the brain stem above the pons will prevent any voluntary changes in ventilation by cutting the pathways from the higher centres.

questions.text: The cardiovascular responses to isotonic exercise include an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Stroke volume

During exercise, sympathetic stimulation of the heart increases the contractility and thus, the stroke volume. A decrease in venous compliance, caused by sympathetic stimulation, increases the venous return to the heart, which also increases stroke volume by a Frank- Starling mechanism. The increased stroke volume, coupled with an increase in heart rate, causes an increase in cardiac output. Systemic arterial pressure also increases in response to the increase in cardiac output. Exercise causes release of local metabolites in muscles which leads to local vasodilation. This in turn decreases the total peripheral resistance resulting in a decrease in DBP. The pulmonary blood vessels also undergo a passive dilatation as more blood flows into the pulmonary circulation. As a result, pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

questions.text: A spirometer cannot be used directly to measure all of the following except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Vital capacity

Routine spirometry cannot measure residual volume, FRC and TLC.

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent boy is being treated with the macrolide antibiotic erythromycin complains of nausea, intestinal cramping, and diarrhoea. The side effects are the result of the antibiotic binding to receptors in the GI tract that recognize which gastrointestinal hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Motilin

Erythromycin group of drugs bind to motilin-like receptors in the GI tract. Motilin stimulates increased contractions by a direct action on smooth muscle and by activation of excitatory enteric nerves. This results in increased intestinal motility, abdominal cramping and diarrhoea.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man has a cerebrovascular accident in the medulla and pons that completely eliminates all vagal output to the GI tract. Which of the following will be totally lost in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Primary oesophageal peristalsis, Primary oesophageal peristalsis is mediated by the vagus. Secondary oesophageal peristalsis is mediated by the local plexus. Although vagus stimulates gastric acid secretion and pancreatic bicarbonate secretion these can be activated by hormonal mechanisms as well.

choices.text: Recent transfusion with banked blood

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the Emergency with shortness of breath. His OHDC was shifted from that for normal haemoglobin A depicted in the curve A in the figure given below to curve B. this finding is consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Recent transfusion with banked blood

In banked blood, glycolysis is inhibited which decreases the 2,3-BPG, shifting the OHDC to the left.

questions.text: A 80-year-old man has a solid tumour that pushes against an airway, partially obstructing the airflow to the distal alveoli. Which point on the V/Q line of the O2- CO2 diagram given below corresponds to the alveolar gas of the distal alveoli?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Partial obstruction of the airway decreases the V/Q ratio. A decrease in the V/Q decrease the Po2 and increases the Pco2 as at point B. At point A, V/Q ratio = zero. At this point the alveolar air equlibrates with the mixed venous blood entering the lung, which causes the gas component of the alveolar air to become identical to that of the blood.

questions.text:
The following figure shows a forced expiration for a healthy person and a patient complaining of shortness of breath.

 The patient most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Emphysema In the patient the FVC is reduced. FEV1 which is the forcefully expired volume of air in one second is also reduced. However, the FEV1/FVC ratio in the patient is markedly reduced. A marked reduction in FEV1/FVC ratio is typically seen in obstructive lung disease, such as emphysema. FEV1/ FVC ratio will also be decreased in old age. However, marked reduction such as seen in the figure points towards emphysema. In restrictive lung disease, FEV1/FVC ratios is normal to increased. In these asbestosis and other diseases characterized by interstitial fibrosis the radial traction on the airways is increased. That is, the airways are held open to a greater extent at any given lung volume, reducing their resistance to airflow.

choices.text: Normal individuals after waking in the morning
Normal individuals who have taken dexamethasone
Patients with Cushing’s syndrome (adrenal adenoma)

questions.text: The plasma levels of both ACTH and cortisol would be expected to be higher in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Normal individuals after waking in the morning

In healthy subjects, the secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are low in the late evening but high in the early morning. In patients with Cushing’s syndrome (adrenal adenoma) or in patients taking dexamethasone, plasma levels of ACTH will be very low. In patients with Addison’s plasma levels of ACTH will be elevated due to deficient adrenal cortisol secretion.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with weakness affecting the proximal muscles is found to have a mutation of a gene that encodes for the protein dystrophin. Genetic alteration in dystrophin lead to progressive muscle weakness because dystrophin provides structural support to the sarcolemma by binding with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Actin to β- dystroglycan

The large dystrophin molecule (molecular weight 427,000) is a rod-like protein that connects the thin actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a serious form of dystrophy in which dystrophin is absent from muscle. It is X-linked and usually fatal by age 30. In a milder form of the disease, Becker muscular dystrophy, dustrophin is present but absent or reduced in amount.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is found comatose in her kitchen by her husband and is brought to the Emergency of a nearby hospital. Blood gas analysis reveals normal Po2 and a lower-than-normal arterial O2 saturation. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with the findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

CO poisoning A normal Po2 and lower-than-normal So2 is indicative of anemic hypoxia. CO poisoning causes anemic hypoxia.

choices.text: Dominance of the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leading to rigidity of extensors in lower limbs
Rubrospinal excitation of flexors of upper limbs
Spasticity is due to facilitation of the gamma loop
Spasticity is due to inhibition of gamma loop

questions.text: A 61-year-old man had a cardiac arrest on the golf course. Almost 8 minutes of resuscitation, normal sinus rhythm with a blood pressure of 110/75 mm Hg is obtained. His neurologic examination done in the hospital one hour after the cardiac arrest reveals decorticate posturing and no eye opening in response to pain. The pupils are reactive. Oculocephalic and corneal reflexes are present but reduced bilaterally. All of the following are the physiological bases of decorticate posturing except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Spasticity is due to inhibition of gamma loop.  Decortication is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs (“mummy posturing”). The flexion in upper limbs is explained by rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscled in the upper limbs. Hyperextension of the lower limbs is due to dominance of the excitatory reticulospinal pathway, which in turn indirectly activate the αmotor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity) which is called the gamma loop.

questions.text: Which of the following vasoactive agents is usually the most important controller of coronary blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Adenosine

Although bradykinin, prostaglandins, potassium ions cause a coronary vasodilation but he major controller of coronary blood flow is adenosine.

questions.text: After secretion of trypsinogen into the duodenum, the enzyme is converted into its active form, trypsin, by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

enteropeptidase

Enteropeptidase or enterokinase converts trypsinogen into its active form- trypsin Trypsin in turn will inactivate all inactive pancreatic proteolytic enzymes to their active form.

questions.text: Inhibition of the sodium iodide symport would be expected to cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Increased thyroglobulin synthesis

Inhibition of NIS will lead to decreased secretion of the thyroid hormones which in turn will cause an increase in TSH secretion from the anterior pituitary. Increased plasma level of TSH stimulates the thyroid follicular cells to synthesize more thyroglobulin.

questions.text: In addition to increasing the permeability of the collecting ducts to water, ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Urea

ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water and urea. The increased urea permeability increases the urea concentration and osmolality of the medullary interstitial fluid surrounding the loop of henle and the distal nephron.

choices.text: Percent O2 saturation in the arterial blood

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive bleeding during her periods and increasing fatigue and cold extremities. Laboratory investigations reveal a Hb of 7gm/dL. In this patient with anemia, which of the following would be reduced?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Total arterial oxygen content

Oxygen content = (Hb in gm/dL X 1.34 X %saturation) + (Po2 in mm Hg X 0.003mL/dL/mm Hg)

If there is a decrease in Hb, the arterial O2 content of the blood will also be reduced. Oxygen extraction by the tissues increases to compensate for the reduced oxygen delivery to the tissues. Arterial O2, dissolved oxygen and the percentage saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen are all normal in anemia.

questions.text: A stroke that destroys the respiratory area of the medulla would be expected to lead to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Immediate cessation of breathing The respiratory centre in the medulla controls all aspects of breathing. A stroke affecting this area will lead to immediate cessation of breathing.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a 40-year history of alcoholism and liver disease visits his physician because of sudden weight gain. One year ago, the man had a BMI of 24.9 kg/m2 and today his BMI is 28.5 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a pitting pedal oedema and moderate ascites. Which condition is most likely to have promoted the development of both ascites and peripheral oedema in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Decreased colloid osmotic pressure Alcohol liver disease and cirrhosis lead to decreased albumin production by the liver. This decreases the colloid osmotic pressure which in turn leads to increased tissue fluid formation especially in the lower limbs (pedal oedema). Ascites is due to two reasons: (i) decreased colloid osmotic pressure, and (ii) increased capillary hydrostatic pressure in the splanchnic organs. In liver cirrhosis, damaged liver parenchymal cells are replaced by fibrous tissue that eventually contracts around the blood vessels, thereby increasing the vascular resistance which in turn leads to increase in portal vein pressure. Increase in portal venous pressure raises the capillary hydrostatic pressure of the splanchnic organs leading to ascites.

questions.text: The renal clearance of phosphate is increased by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

PTH

PTH decreases the inorganic reabsorption in the PCT. Increase in urinary concentration of inorganic phosphorus increases the renal clearance of phosphorus.

(Phosphorus is a mineral that combines with other substances to form organic and inorganic phosphate compounds. The terms phosphorus and phosphate are used interchangeably.)

questions.text: Which of the following is not produced by osteoblasts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Pyrophosphate

Osteoblasts secrete all except pyrophosphate. Alkaline phosphatase from osteoblasts neutralize pyrophosphate, an inhibitor of hydroxyapatite crystallization. Neutralization of pyrophosphate permits the precipitation of calcium salts into collagen fibres.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with severe kyphoscoliosis and respiratory muscle weakness. Which of the following physiological variables is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Chest wall compliance

Kyphoscoliosis is a restrictive lung disease. In RLD, all lung volumes and chest wall compliance decrease but FEV1/ FVC ratio is normal to increased. Decreased chest wall compliance and respiratory muscle weakness cause inadequate alveolar ventilation which leads to accumulation of CO2 and respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents with lethargy, confusion and muscle cramps. Lab investigations reveal elevated ADH levels, possible from the ectopic production of ADH. In patients with SIADH, which of the following will increase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Intracellular volume

ADH will increase water reabsorption increasing the ECF volume and decreasing the plasma sodium and plasma osmolality. Decrease in plasma osmolality will cause shift of water from ECf to ICF increasing the intracellular volume. Since there is increased reabsorption of water urine flow rate will decrease.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman has a mass in the sella turcica that compresses the portal vessels, disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion rate of which hormone would most likely increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Prolactin

Prolactin secretion is inhibited by hypothalamic PIF. All others are stimulated by hypothalamic hormones.  Obstruction of blood flow through the hypothalamic- hypophyseal portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, TSH, GH, FSH, LH, but increased secretion of Prolactin.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy playing in his garden accidentally steps on a broken bottle with his bare right foot. His right leg immediately lifts up while his left leg extends even before he cries out in pain. Which of the following best describes the type of reflex and the centre involved in this reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Polysynaptic; spinal

This is an example of crossed extensor reflex elicited by a painful stimulus. Crossed extensor is a polysynaptic and spinal reflex.

choices.text: Excitation of amygdala by slow pain fibres
Excitation of reticular formation by slow pain fibres
Depression of amygdala by slow pain fibres
Depression of reticular formation by slow pain fibres

questions.text: A 73-year-old man sustained a lower back injury that causes severe chronic pain. His physician prescribes analgesics for the pain and benzodiazepines to help him sleep. Which of the following best describes why this man has difficulty sleeping without medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Excitation of reticular formation by slow pain fibres

Slow pain pathway gives excitatory fibres to the reticular formation. Excitation of the reticular formation excites the ascending reticular activating system which in turn keeps him alert and awake.

choices.text: Motor function and temperature sensation

questions.text: A 20-year-old man, victim of road traffic accident is brought to the Emergency and is diagnosed with hemisection of the left side of the spinal cord at C6. Which of the following function is likely to be lost in the right leg of this man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Pain and temperature

This is a patient of Brown Sequard syndrome. Pain and temperature will be lost on the opposite side below the level of lesion.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl  fell from her bicycle and sustained a head injury. She develops a fever of 39 degrees Celsius which is unrelated to an infection or inflammation. The fever is most likely due to a lesion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Anterior hypothalamus

Anterior hypothalamus is responsible for initiating reflexes such as, vasodilation and sweating, which help reduce body temperature. Lesion of this area can therefore, increase body temperature.

questions.text: Precentral gyrus, corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts are essential for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Voluntary movement

The precentral gyrus is the motor cortex that contains cell bodies of the neurons that form the corticospinal tract (also referred to as the pyramidal tract).

questions.text: Synaptic transmission between the pain fibres from the viscera in the pelvis to spinal cord neurons is mediated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Substance P

The neurotransmitter secreted by C fibres for visceral pain is substance P.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of agitation and aggression. Three years prior to admission, her irregular, flicking movements had become so severe that she could not walk or look after herself. Huntington chorea affects which of the following areas of the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Caudate nucleus

Huntington chorea is an inherited genetic defect leading to the degeneration of neurons within the caudate nucleus.

choices.text: Increasing the potassium permeability of the pre-synaptic nerve ending
Increasing the potassium permeability of the α-motor neuron
Hyperpolarizing the membrane potential of the α-motor neuron
Increasing the amount of neurotransmitter released by the pre-synaptic membrane

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis and increasing spasticity is treated with an intrathecal infusion of baclofen, a GABAB agonist which mediates pre-synaptic inhibition. Presynaptic inhibition in the CNS affects the firing rate of α-motor neurons by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Increasing the potassium permeability of the pre-synaptic nerve ending

Baclofen, a GABAB agonist, acting via a G-protein increases the potassium conductance, causing hyperpolarization of the pre-synaptic membrane, which in turn causes a pre-synaptic inhibition of the motor pathway, decreasing the spasticity.

questions.text: The circadian rhythm is controlled by which hypothalamic nucleus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Suprachiasmatic

Suprachiasmatic nucleus controls secretion of melatonin from the pineal gland. Melatonin, in turn, is responsible for several circadian rhythms, including sleep-wake cycles.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a past h/o cirrhosis undergoes a total colectomy. Removal of the entire colon would be expected to cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Increase in blood ammonia

One of the actions of colonic bacteria is to convert ammonia to ammonium ion. Thus, the total colectomy will increase the blood ammonia levels, which would be exacerbated in a patient with cirrhosis.

questions.text: A group of university students visit Khardungla at 5600 metres. On arrival, few of the students experience mental and muscle fatigue, and complain of headaches, nausea, and dyspnoea. Which of the following will be decreased in these patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Paco2

Hypoxia at high altitude stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors to increase ventilation, causing the arterial Paco2 to decrease and arterial pH to rise. Hypoxia also increases 2,3- BPG concentration. Alveolar hypoxia causes a pulmonary vasoconstriction which increases the pulmonary vascular resistance.

questions.text:
A medical student is studying the fluid exchange in skeletal muscle capillaries in a laboratory animal. He determines that fluid is being filtered out of the capillaries with a net filtration pressure of 10mmHg. He obtains the following values –

Capillary hydrostatic pressure is 45mmHg

Capillary oncotic pressure is 25 mmHg

Interstitial oncotic pressure is 10mmHg

Which of the following is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Starling forces govern the rate of filtration across capillaries. It depends on four pressures – capillary hydrostatic pressure, capillary oncotic pressure, interstitial hydrostatic pressure and interstitial oncotic pressure. So, NFP= PCap + πIF – PIF – πcap .  From the above data,

10= 45+ 10 – 25 + πIF   = 30 + πIF , hence πIF= 20mmHg.

choices.text: Risk of decompression sickness is reduced
Risk of O2 toxicity is reduced

questions.text: If helium oxygen mixture rather than nitrogen-oxygen mixture is given to a deep sea diver, which of the following will be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Risk of decompression sickness is reduced

Helium being a less soluble gas as compared to nitrogen is less likely to cause inert gas narcosis and decompression sickness. Helium is a less dense gas- therefore, it will reduce resistance to airflow and work of breathing.

choices.text: Low oxygen tension decreases his skeletal muscle blood flow
Low oxygen tension increases the skeletal muscle lactate
Plasma proteins are more ionized under alkalotic conditions which provide more protein anion to bind with Ca++
Stimulation of the sodium-potassium ATPase reduces the plasma concentration of free ionized calcium

questions.text: A 22- year-old man is planning to run the 10k when he goes to visit his brother in Leh. Because of the high altitude, he decides to leave early for the event. While in Leh, he experiences extensive cramping and spasms in his calf muscles while running, symptoms he seldom experienced in Delhi. Lab tests reveal hypocalcemia. Which of the following is the reason high altitude predisposes to tetany?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Plasma proteins are more ionized under alkalotic conditions which provide more protein anion to bind with Ca++

Low oxygen tension at high altitude stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors which in turn increase the rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in alveolar ventilation causes respiratory alkalosis. Under alkalotic conditions, plasma proteins are more ionized which provide more protein anion to bind with Ca++. Decrease in free calcium causes loss of membrane stabilizing action of calcium increasing neuronal and muscle excitability (k/a hypocalcemic tetany).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with the chief complaint of intermittent mid-epigastric pain that is relieved by antacids or eating. Gastric analysis reveals that basal and maximal acid outputs exceed normal values. The gastric acid hypersecretion can be explained by an increase in the plasma concentration of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Gastrin

Gastrin is the primary stimulus of meal-induced acid secretion by the parietal cells of the stomach. Somatostatin, VIP, secretin, CCK inhibit gastric acid secretion.

Increases in basal and maximal acid output are suggestive of inflammation or removal of the proximal small intestine. Intestinal receptors monitor the composition of the gastric chyme and elicit feedback mechanisms that regulate the gastric acid secretion and gastric emptying. Absence of feedback leads to an increased presence of excitatory mediators of gastric function.

Hypergastrinemia in ZES causes hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa, leading to increased numbers of parietal cells and increased maximal acid output. Gastrin by itself also stimulates acid secretion.

choices.text: Adapted for slow and sustained contraction

questions.text: The diagram below illustrates single isometric twitch contractions of two skeletal muscles, A and B, in response to a depolarizing stimulus. Which of the following best describes the muscle A?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Muscle A is Fast muscle fiber adapted for phasic contractions- these have large muscle fibers, faster conduction velocity, dependent upon anaerobic metabolism and innervated by large muscle fibers.

questions.text: The body fluid volume changes in a 34 year old patient are shown below in Darrow-Yannet diagram (solid line – normal, dotted line – patient). Which of the following is the cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Darrow Yannet diagram depicts in this case that osmolarity has increased and ECF volume has decreased – this can happen only in loss of hypotonic fluid – which occurs in diabetes insipidus – less ADH or failure of action of ADH – leading to decreased reabsorption of water in the collecting ducts.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient is recovering from acute lung injury following a diffuse pulmonary viral infection. The cell type responsible for the regeneration of the patient's alveolar epithelium is also functions in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

In acute lung injury (ALI), damaged alveolar epithelial cells are regenerated by type II pneumocytes; these are the same cells that secrete surfactant. 
The major cell type composing the alveolar epithelium (90-95%) are the type I pneumocytes. Type II pneumocytes compose about 5% of the alveolar wall, however, they are more numerous overall. Type II pneumocytes have the important function of regenerating damaged pneumocytes and secreting surfactant from their lamellar bodies. 
Protease release is more consistent with a function of neutrophils. 
Phagocytosis is a function more consistent with macrophages. Mucus secretion is more consistent with the function of goblet cells

questions.text: A 75-year-old overweight male patient reports frequent urination, and his blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg. Based on a 24-hour inulin clearance, his GFR is estimated to be 150mL/min. his plasma glucose is 400mg/dL. Assuming that his renal transport maxima for glucose is 300mg/min, as shown in the figure given below, what would be the approximate rate of urinary glucose excretion for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

300mg/min

Filtered rate = GFR X plasma concentration

At a plasma glucose of 400 mg/dL or 4 mg/mL, the filtered rate of glucose is 150 X 4 = 600mg/min.

Urinary excretion rate can be calculated as the filtered rate of glucose minus the transport maxima. The rate of transport maxima for glucose is 300mg/min, the rate of glucose excretion would be 600 minus 300 = 300 mg/min.

questions.text: In the following graph, plasma concentration is given on the x-axis and renal clearance of different substances is given on the y-axis. Which of the following depicts the renal clearance of para-amino hippuric acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

PAHA in low concentration (< 20mg/dL) is freely filtered and competed secreted resulting in a very high clearance of PAHA. At high concentration there is incomplete secretion of PAHA resulting in a decrease in PAHA clearance.

choices.text: Lateral hemisphere and interposed nucleus
Intermediate zone and fastigial nucleus

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the cerebellum is involved in planning of sequential movement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Cerebrocerebellum and dentate nucleus

Cerebrocerebellum and dentate nucleus are involved in motor planning.

questions.text: Shown in the graph given below is the time taken by four receptors for adaptation. Which line represents the Pacinian corpuscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Line A Pacinian corpuscle is a very rapidly adapting touch receptor. The impulses generated per second in the receptor represented by line A very rapidly touch the baseline, indicating that this is a very rapidly adapting receptor.

questions.text: An increase in the shear stress in a blood vessel is likely to cause which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Increased NO production

An increase in shear stress in blood vessels is one of the main stimuli for the release of NO by endothelial cells. NO increases blood flow by increasing cGMP.

choices.text: More the force or the afterload, less is the velocity of contraction
Vmax is when the afterload is zero
When Velocity = zero contraction is completely isometric
Less the afterload, less is the tension generated in the muscle

questions.text:
The following graph shows the force-velocity relationship for isotonic muscle contractions of skeletal muscles.

Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the force- velocity relationship?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Less the afterload, less is the tension generated in the muscle

Tension generated in a muscle during isometric muscle contractions is determined by the preload.

questions.text: Most of the following GI secretions have a basal output during the inter-digestive period (between meals). However, the sight and smell of a tasty meal stimulates GI secretions. Of the various GI secretions, which is the most stimulated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

 Explanation- cephalic phase causes maximum salivary secretion.

questions.text: The pleural pressure of a normal 40-year-old male is approximately -5 cm H2O during resting conditions immediately before inspiration (i.e., at FRC). What is his pleural pressure during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

-8 cm H2O

Pleural pressure becomes more negative during inspiration.

questions.text: In a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus caused by a complete lack of ADH secretion, which part of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

In the absence of ADH, the late DCT and CD are not permeable to water. Therefore, the tubular fluid, which is already dilute when it leaves the loop of Henle (about 100mOsm/L), becomes further dilute as it flows through the late DCT and collecting tubules as more electrolytes are reabsorbed. Therefore, the final urine osmolality in the complete absence of ADH will be lower than 100mOsm/L.

questions.text:
Shown below is the location of the high –pressure baroreceptors

Physiology PG clamps the carotid sinus at ‘A’ and ‘B’ separately (i.e. in 2 separate experiments), He is likely to observe which of the following change in BP respectively:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Clamping at A results in less perfusion and less stretching of baroreceptors so baroreceptors will increase the BP whereas in B results in overstretching of baroreceptors resulting in decreased BP.

choices.text: Binding of O2 to hemoglobin in lungs drives release of CO2 from haemoglobin
The sum of the partial pressures of CO2 and O2 cannot exceed a known threshold in blood
High partial pressure of CO2 in tissues facilitates O2 unloading in peripheral tissues
High partial pressure of CO2 in tissues causes alkalemia, which is necessary for O2 unloading

questions.text: A research scientist attempts to understand the influence of carbon dioxide content in blood on its oxygen binding. The scientist adds carbon dioxide to dog blood and measures the uptake of oxygen in the blood versus oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue. He notes in one dog that with the addition of carbon dioxide with a pressure of 90 mmHg, the oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue rose from 26 to 33 mmHg. How can this phenomenon be explained?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Bohr effect is seen with increase in PCO2 more O2 is released to the tissues ie. It causes right shift of the curve.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs best describes the relationship between Pco2 and alveolar ventilation (VA), when the Pco2 is changed acutely over a range of 35 to 75 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

The relationship between increasing Pco2 and its effect on alveolar ventilation is linear. More the Pco2 more will be the alveolar ventilation. The increase in VA can be almost 8 times when the arterial CO2 tension is increased over a physiological range from 35 to 75 mm Hg.

choices.text: Stretch reflex- Golgi tendon organ
Autogenic inhibition- Golgi tendon organ

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes is correctly paired with its receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Autogenic inhibition- Golgi tendon organ

Receptors for the stretch reflex (also k/a myotactic reflex or deep tendon jerk) are the muscle spindles. Reciprocal inhibition is also mediated by the muscle spindles. Receptors for the inverse stretch reflex (also k/a autogenic inhibition) are the Golgi tendon organs. Nociceptor stimulation is responsible for the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor responses
